newsitem.title: USA: Whittman-Hart can't account for activity.
newsitem.headline: Whittman-Hart can't account for activity.

text.p: Whittman-Hart Inc said it could not account for the volatility in its shares which fell as much as 3-1/8 to 19-5/8 earlier in the session and recovered to trade in a narrow range Tuesday afternoon.

The company also Tuesday filed with federal regulators for a shelf offering of more than four million common shares. A company spokesman said the shares will be available for future acquisitions, although no deals were pending.
"I have no idea why the stock fell," said Robert Bernard, Whittman-Hart's chairman. "It has nothing to do with any news from our company or anything related to our business."
The shares closed off 1/2 at 22-5/8 on turnover of more than 162,000 shares.
Whittman-Hart, which went public in May at 16 a share, designs and installs computer system projects. It completed an offering of two million shares at 28-1/2 in August.
The sell-off was apparently related to buyers taking profits from small-cap stocks before the end of the year, said one analyst who asked not to identified.

"Given how well they've performed in the market, it's not a surprise they're a little volatile given their high price-to-earnings ratio," explained Mark Whitcher, an investment banker at Broadview Associates.
"They're experiencing expanding growth in terms of coverage," Whitcher said, "and the demand for their services is skyrocketing."
